source.raw_text:
The Kettlebell (KB) V-Sit Pass-Over (also known as a V-sit with pass the weight, or a variation of a kettlebell figure-eight in a V-sit) is a demanding core exercise that primarily engages your abdominal muscles and hip flexors through controlled rotation and stability. [1, 2]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary: 

    • Rectus Abdominis: The "six-pack" muscles are heavily engaged to maintain the V-sit position and stabilize the torso. 
    • Obliques (External and Internal): These muscles are targeted as you twist and pass the kettlebell from side to side, controlling the rotational movement. 
    • Hip Flexors: These muscles work hard to keep your legs elevated and maintain the "V" shape. 
    • Transverse Abdominis: The deep core muscles act as stabilizers to protect the spine and maintain balance throughout the movement. 

• Secondary/Stabilizers: 

    • Erector Spinae: These lower back muscles help maintain an upright posture and prevent the back from rounding. 
    • Shoulders and Arms: The muscles in your shoulders, biceps, triceps, and forearms are engaged to hold and control the kettlebell, improving grip strength and shoulder stability. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]  

Movement Patterns 
The KB V-Sit Pass-Over incorporates several functional movement patterns: 

• Trunk Rotation/Anti-Rotation: The core must stabilize the body while the upper body rotates to pass the weight, building core control and strength. 
• Core Stabilization: The exercise requires significant isometric strength to hold the V-sit position and resist the force of the moving kettlebell trying to pull you off balance. 
• Flexion/Extension Control: Maintaining the balance in the V-sit requires continuous control over the flexion of the hips and stabilization of the spine. 
• Coordination and Balance: The dynamic nature of passing the kettlebell around and between the legs challenges balance and hand-eye coordination. [1, 5, 6, 7, 9]
